book-title-group.subtitle: History, Evil, Desire, and Modern Japanese Literature

abstract.p: If the postmodernist ethical onslaught has led to the demise of literature by exposing its political agenda, if all literature is compromised by its entanglement with power, why does literature’s subterranean voice still seduce us into reading? Why do the madness and the scandal of transgressive literature, its power to force us to begin anew, its evil, escape the gaze of contemporary literary criticism? Why do we dare not reject ethics and the ethical approach to literature? If the primary task of literary criticism is to correct others’ ethical missteps, should we not begin by confronting the seductiveness of ethics, our desire for ethics, the pleasure we take in being ethical? And what is the relationship between ethics and history in the study of literature? What would be the ethical consequences of an erasure of history from literary criticism? In a series of essays on the writings of Kawabata Yasunari, Murakami Haruki, Karatani Kjin, Furui Yoshikichi, Mishima Yukio, Oe Kenzaburo, Natsume Soseki, and Kobayashi Hideo, Hosea Hirata visits the primal force of the scandalous in an effort to repeat (in the Kierkegaardian sense) the originary scene that initiates the obscure yet insistent poetry that is literature and to confront the questions raised.

A poem as a scandal begins a book on modern Japanese prose texts. It opens this book, not because this particular poem historically, geographically, or culturally circumscribes the primary texts that are to be analyzed— works by Kawabata Yasunari, Murakami Haruki, Karatani Kojin, Furui Yoshikichi, Mishima Yukio, Ōe ken zaburŌ, Natsume SŌseki, and Kobayashi Hideo— but simply because it isscandalousin the most elementary sense. title-group.label: CHAPTER 5
title-group.title: Masturbation, the Emperor, and the Language of the Sublime in Ōe Kenzaburō

abstract.p: Masturbation, the Emperor, and the language of the sublime: these rather disparate terms may be considered synecdoches for separate yet intricately linked discourses, namely, the sexual, the political, and the literary. It was the young Ōe Kenzaburō (b. 1935 ), barely out of college, who began to fuse these discourses in his fictional works during the period surrounding the politically turbulent year 1960. The most controversial work of this period was his novella “Sevunt i n” (“Seventeen”) along with its sequel “Seiji shōnen shisu” (“The political youth dies”) published in the January and February issues of the journalBungakukaiin

In 1963 , the same year “Seiteki ningen” (Sexual human being; English translation published under the title “J”) was published, one of the most significant events in Ōe Kenzaburō’s life took place: his son, Hikari, was born with severe brain damage. The next year he published his epoch-makingKojintekina taiken(A personal matter), in which he dramatized his “murderous” relationship with his newborn son. Ōe was to repeat and modulate this “personal” subject obsessively in his subsequent works. title-group.title: The Emergence of History in Natsume Sōseki’s Kokoro

abstract.p: Something has broken—a thread of life, perhaps. Something horrifying, something irreversible, has happened. This is what many of us mumble to ourselves as we close Kokoro (1914). In the same breath, we say, something remains, something uncanny lives on, a ghostly presence, a spectral language of ethics.

Thus Natsume S o seki (1867–1916 ), the figure of an exemplarysensei(teacher), remains, canonized in Japanese school textbooks, enshrined on the 1,000 -yen bill. abstract.p: How comforting it is to transliterate his name,小林秀雄, to Kobayashi Hideo (1902–83 ) and, by doing so, jarring, however slightly, a towering presence, dispersing it into the thin air of foreign alphabets, finally.¹ For he has resided at the very center of what we have come to call “Modern Japanese Literature” as its ghostly magistrate, its most masterly father, its first and foremost critic.² He was a poet manqué and a thief of poetry. abstract.p: We may feel a certain poverty in the English language when we try to translate the Japanese word 故郷 pregnant with so much cultural as well as personal resonance. It is a lovely word, the primary catalyst of our nostalgia. The first character 故 suggests a sense of the past and origin; the second 郷indicates a rural village. Thus we see in this word the temporal and the spatial being fused; an irretrievable past¹ and one’s place of origin are being juxtaposed.
